questions.text: A child was referred to an ophthalmologist in view of squint. The child’s eyes had the following appearance. What would be your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pseudo strabismus

 

Option D:

 

  • In the given picture, child has prominent epicanthal folds giving the appearance of esotropia – this is known as Pseudoesotropia / apparent convergent squint.
  • Visual axes remain parallel.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Accommodative Squint: A form of strabismus usually presenting in childhood where the eyes turn inward (esotropia) as a result of excessive effort to accommodate or focus, often correctable with glasses.

 

 

Option B. Essential Infantile Esotropia: A type of early-onset, constant inward turning of one or both eyes (esotropia) that typically appears in infants within the first year of life and often requires surgical correction.

 

 

Option C. Congenital Ptosis: A condition present at birth where the upper eyelid droops over the eye due to underdevelopment or weakness of the eyelid-lifting muscle, potentially obstructing vision if severe.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corneal light reflex is central in both eyes. The child has prominent epicanthal folds giving the appearance of esotropia – this is known as Pseudoesotropia.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no: 341

choices.text: Small angle of squint
Onset is within 2 years of age
Cross fixation in side gaze noted
Presence of significant refractive error

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant with cerebral palsy is brought in by her mother due to a recent onset of eye deviation. The mother reports that the deviation is more noticeable when the child is focusing on objects. The child has no history of trauma, infection, and is up-to-date with vaccinations. During the physical examination, you note that the child's eyes do not align properly, especially in lateral gaze. Based on this presentation, which of the following is the most likely characteristic of this child's strabismus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cross fixation in side gaze noted

 

Option C:

 

  • The given scenario is suggestive of EARLY-ONSET ESOTROPIA.
  • Idiopathic condition.
  • Develops within 6 months of life.
  • Features include
  • Large angle squint
  • Alternate fixation in primary gaze and cross fixation in side gaze
  • No significant refractive error

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Small Angle of Squint: Early onset esotropia often presents with a large angle of squint rather than a small one.

 

Option B. Onset is Within 2 Years of Age: Early onset esotropia, as the name suggests, typically begins in infancy or early childhood. The most common form, congenital or infantile esotropia, often appears before the child reaches 6 months of age.

 

Option D. Presence of Significant Refractive Error: While refractive errors can be associated with some forms of strabismus, early onset esotropia is not typically characterized by significant refractive errors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that early onset esotropia typically presents within the first two years of life, often with large-angle squint and cross fixation behavior, but not necessarily with significant refractive errors.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION pg.no: 728

choices.text: Increase the dose of anaesthesia

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with squint was undergoing corrective surgery. Heart rate recorded prior to initiation was 100 bpm. After anaesthesia and start of surgery, heart rate reduced to 50 bpm. How to intervene further?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Administer Inj. Atropine

 

Option D:

 

  • The response noted in this case is termed as Oculocardiac Reflex / Aschner Dagnini reflex.
  • It is  the slowing of heart rate caused by traction on the EOMs, particularly the medial rectus muscle.
  • In its most severe form, the reflex can produce asystole.
  • Intravenous atropine is administered in the event of this response

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increase the dose of anesthesia:

 

Increasing the dose of anesthesia in the case of bradycardia is generally not advisable. Many anesthetics can depress myocardial function and further reduce heart rate. This action could exacerbate the situation rather than alleviate it.

 

Option B. Administer beta blockers:

 

Beta blockers are contraindicated in this situation. They are typically used to decrease heart rate and blood pressure. Administering beta blockers to a patient who is already experiencing bradycardia could be dangerous, as it could further lower the heart rate, potentially leading to hemodynamic instability.

 

Option C. Cessation of surgery:

 

While it is important to always be prepared to stop surgery if the patient's condition deteriorates significantly, immediate cessation of surgery for bradycardia is not always necessary. The cause of the bradycardia should be identified and treated accordingly. If the bradycardia is directly related to the surgical procedure or anesthesia, then pausing might be considered while corrective measures are taken.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of a significant reduction in heart rate to 50 bpm in a child during surgery, the appropriate intervention is to administer Inj. Atropine. This acts to increase heart rate by antagonizing the vagal effects on the heart, and is a critical response in managing oculocardiac reflex during squint surgery.

 

Ref: AAO SECTION:6 – PAEDIATRIC OPHTHALMOLOGY AND STRABISMUS. PG.NO: 174

questions.text: Based on the evaluation of a patient with strabismus, a 15º primary deviation and 30º secondary deviation were recorded. What type of strabismus does this indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paralytic squint

 

Option C:

 

 

  • In case of paralytic squint – secondary deviation > primary deviation.
  • This is based on HERING’S LAW OF EQUAL INNERVATION OF YOKE MUSCLES.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Concomitant Squint:

 

In concomitant squint (also known as non-paralytic or comitant squint), the degree of deviation remains constant regardless of the direction of gaze. It means that the angle of misalignment does not change when the patient looks in different directions.

 

Primary deviation = Secondary deviation.

 

Option B. Accommodative Esotropia:

 

Accommodative esotropia is a type of concomitant squint where the eyes turn inward. It is often related to uncorrected hyperopia and the eye's effort to accommodate leads to convergence and thus inward turning of the eyes. Like other forms of concomitant squint, the primary and secondary deviations in accommodative esotropia are equal.

 

Option D. Convergence Insufficiency:

 

Convergence insufficiency is a condition where the eyes do not work together well while focusing on a near object. The eyes have difficulty converging adequately for near work, leading to symptoms like eyestrain and blurring - asthenopia. It does not typically present with a difference between primary and secondary deviations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 In a case with a 15º primary deviation and a 30º secondary deviation in strabismus, the diagnosis is indicative of a paralytic squint. This finding is characteristic of paralytic strabismus, where the secondary deviation (when the affected eye is fixating) is greater than the primary deviation (when the unaffected eye is fixating), reflecting the impact of muscle weakness or paralysis.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no 351

questions.text: A patient presented with deviation of right eye in primary gaze. On testing, the corneal reflex was noted to be at the nasal limbus. The deviation in prism diopter is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 90∆ exotropia

 

Option B:

 

  • Tropias (manifest squint) are examined by Hirschberg corneal reflex test.
  • It is performed by shining the light on person’s eye.

 

 

  • The distance between the normal and abnormal reflection is measured and the calculation is done as follows:
    • Every 1 mm = 7 degree squint.
    • 1 degree = 2 prism dioptre.

 

The angle of squint is 15 degree and 45 degree when the corneal light reflex falls on the           border of pupil and limbus respectively.

 

  • In this question, the reflection of light is at the nasal (inner) limbus of the right eye, which means it is 45 degree or 90∆ exotropia.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 45∆ esotropia – Indicates that the Hirschberg reflex should lie between pupil and limbus.

 

Option C. 30∆ esotropia – Indicates that the Hirschberg reflex should lie at the pupillary border.

 

Option D. 60∆ exotropia - Indicates that the Hirschberg reflex should lie between pupil and limbus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The reflection of light is at the nasal (inner) limbus of the right eye, which means it is 45 degree or 90∆ exotropia.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no 347

questions.text: Identify the condition:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Duane’s retraction syndrome

 

Option C:

 

In this picture, primary gaze appears normal. There is limited abduction of left eye in levoversion with narrowing of palpebral fissure on attempted adduction noted. This is characteristic of Duane’s type I retraction syndrome.

 

  • Cause: Due to a fibrosis of the lateral rectus or an innervational anomaly with cocontraction of the lateral and medial recti.
  •  In the primary position: The eyes are straight or show some latent convergence, but there is a restriction or absence of abduction.
  • On adduction: There is a retraction of the globe and a narrowing of the palpebral fissure because this syndrome is an exception to Sherrington rule of reciprocal innervation.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Möbius Syndrome: A rare congenital disorder characterized by facial paralysis and the inability to move the eyes laterally due to cranial nerve VI and VII dysfunctions.

 

Option B. Brown Syndrome: A condition marked by defects in the superior oblique tendon sheath, leading to restriction in the upward movement of the eye, particularly when it is adducted.

 

Option D. Marcus Gunn Syndrome: Also known as Marcus Gunn Jaw-Winking Phenomenon, it is a rare congenital condition where the upper eyelid rises abnormally when the jaw moves, due to aberrant nerve connections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retraction of globe on attempted horizontal eye movements with restriction of adduction and abduction is suggestive of Duane’s syndrome.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PG.NO: 736

questions.text: A child was brought to the ophthalmologist with complaint of inability to look up. On examination it is noticed that on attempted upgaze, there are convergence-like movements accompanied by retraction of the globe. A lesion involving the vertical gaze nucleus is suspected. Which of the following is the nucleus for upward gaze?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interstitial nucleus of Cajal

 

Option C:

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cuneiform Nucleus: The cuneiform nucleus is part of the midbrain but is not specifically associated with control of upward gaze. It is involved in various functions including modulating the pain response and controlling certain aspects of autonomic function.

 

Option B. Paramedian Pontine Reticular Formation (PPRF): The PPRF is crucial for horizontal eye movements, particularly for initiating rapid eye movements known as saccades. It is located in the pons and is not directly responsible for upward gaze.

 

Optin D. Edinger-Westphal Nucleus: The Edinger-Westphal nucleus is part of the oculomotor nuclear complex and is primarily associated with the parasympathetic control of the eye, contributing to pupillary constriction and accommodation, rather than eye movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Interstitial Nucleus of Cajal, located in the midbrain, is responsible for the control of upward gaze.

 

Ref: PARSON’S DISEASES OF EYE PG.NO: 411

questions.text: A patient underwent recession of medial rectus for esotropia. After the surgery, a small angle residual squint was noted. A patient developed esotropia secondary to CN6 palsy. The resultant dipopia was hindring day-to-day activities. An injection was given to medial rectus muscle to correct the squint. Identify the drug used:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Botulinum

 

Option C:

 

  • This process of utilization of drug to treat squint temporarily is termed as chemo denervation.
  • Temporary paralysis of an extraocular muscle can be induced by an injection of botulinum toxin under topical anaesthesia and electromyographic (EMG) control.
  • The effect takes several days to develop, is usually maximal at 1–2 weeks following injection and has generally worn off by 3 months.
  • An extraocular muscle lengthens while it is paralyzed by botulinum and its antagonist contracts.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Edrophonium: This is a cholinesterase inhibitor commonly used in the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis. It has no role in the treatment of squint.

 

Option B. Atropine: An anticholinergic drug, used in ophthalmology primarily to dilate pupils and paralyze accommodation. It is not used via injection for squint correction.

 

Option D. Adrenaline: Primarily used in emergency situations for its vasoconstrictive and bronchodilating effects, adrenaline has no therapeutic role in the direct treatment of squint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The drug used for injection into the medial rectus muscle to correct squint is Botulinum toxin, as it temporarily paralyzes the muscle, aiding in the realignment of the eyes.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 743

questions.text: Identify the condition:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brown syndrome

 

Option B:

 

  • This picture shows defect in elevation of right eye in adducted position – suggestive of BROWN’S SUPERIOR OBLIQUE TENDON SHEATH SYNDROME.
  • Inability to elevate an adducted eye can be due to:
    • Inferior oblique paresis (rare)
    • Superior oblique muscle causing mechanical restriction

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Möbius syndrome: Characterized by congenital facial paralysis and abducens nerve palsy, leading to limited facial expression and lateral gaze palsy.

 

 

Option C. Marcus Gunn syndrome (Marcus Gunn Jaw-Winking Phenomenon): Involves an abnormal connection between the muscles of jaw movement and the eyelid, causing the upper eyelid to elevate involuntarily during jaw movement.

 

 

Option D. Duane’s syndrome: Marked by limited horizontal eye movement, often with retraction of the eyeball into the socket and narrowing of the eyelid opening when trying to look inward or outward.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brown syndrome presents with inability to elevate the affected eye in adduction due to a restriction in the superior oblique tendon.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no 355

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient came with complaint of inability to look up following a hit to the eye with a tennis ball. On examination, the forced duction test is positive. What is the muscle abnormality in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior rectus entrapment

 

Option C:

 

 

  • The given scenario suggests entrapment of inferior rectus muscle - form of restrictive squint.
  • Smaller deviation in primary position in proportion to limitation of ocular movement.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Superior rectus entrapment: This muscle is responsible for upward gaze, but entrapment is less likely because it is not commonly entrapped following orbital trauma.

 

Option B. Superior rectus palsy: Palsy would imply a nerve dysfunction, which is less likely given the positive forced duction test indicating a mechanical restriction.

 

Option D. Inferior rectus palsy: Similar to superior rectus palsy, this would suggest nerve dysfunction, not a mechanical restriction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The likely muscle abnormality in a patient with trauma to the eye, inability to look up, and a positive forced duction test is entrapment of the inferior rectus muscle.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no 355

choices.text: Presence of vertical gaze palsy

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Möbius syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bilateral presentation

 

Option C:

 

  • Möbius syndrome is characterised by congenital non-progressive bilateral sixth and seventh cranial nerve palsies.
  • There is a developmental abnormality of the brainstem.
  • Major Features:
  • Bilateral facial palsy - expressionless facial appearance
  • Bilateral sixth nerve palsy .
  • Horizontal gaze palsy

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Presence of vertical gaze palsy: Möbius syndrome primarily involves horizontal gaze palsy due to abducens (6th cranial nerve) and facial (7th cranial nerve) nerve paralysis. Vertical gaze palsy is not a characteristic feature.

 

Option B. Acquired progressive condition: Möbius syndrome is a congenital, non-progressive condition. It is present from birth and does not worsen over time.

 

Option D. Only 6th nerve involvement: While the 6th cranial nerve (abducens nerve) is involved in Möbius syndrome, it is not the only nerve affected. The 7th cranial nerve (facial nerve) is also typically involved, leading to facial muscle weakness or paralysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Möbius syndrome is characterized by its bilateral presentation, involving paralysis of the 6th (abducens) and 7th (facial) cranial nerves, leading to facial weakness and horizontal gaze palsy; it is a congenital and non-progressive condition.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION pg.no: 736

choices.text: Recession of right lateral rectus and medial rectus
Resection of right lateral rectus and medial rectus
Resection of right lateral rectus and recession of right medial rectus
Recession of right lateral rectus and resection of right medial rectus

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient came to the OPD with a complaint of double vision since few months which was worse for distant objects. The patient gave a history of deviation of one eye since childhood. On examination,right esotropia was noted and after further evaluation, a diagnosis of right lateral rectus palsy was made. What is the ideal surgical procedure for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Resection of right lateral rectus and recession of right medial rectus

 

Option C:

 

  • In case of paralytic squint, surgical treatment is done if recovery doesn’t occur in 6 months.
  • PRINCIPLES OF SURGICAL CORRECTION
    • Strengthen the paralysed muscle by resection.
    • Weaken the overacting muscle by recession.
    • In advanced cases, transplantation of normal muscle tendon adjacent to paralysed muscle tendon.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Recession of right lateral rectus and medial rectus: This would not be ideal for lateral rectus palsy. Recession (weakening) of the already palsied lateral rectus would exacerbate the problem, and recessing the medial rectus of the same eye could lead to significant imbalance.

 

Option B. Resection of right lateral rectus and medial rectus: Resecting (shortening/strengthening) the palsied lateral rectus might be considered, but resecting the medial rectus in the same eye typically would not be indicated as it would further imbalance the eye.

 

Option D. Recession of right lateral rectus and resection of right medial rectus: Recession (weakening) of a palsied muscle and resection (strengthening) of its antagonist will worsen the squint and the diplopia in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with right lateral rectus palsy, the ideal surgical intervention typically involves resecting (strengthening) the weak right lateral rectus and recessing (weakening) the opposing right medial rectus to restore ocular balance and alignment.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no: 354

questions.text: Identify the given scenario:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dissociated vertical deviation

 

Option C:

 

  • In the given picture, eyes appear orthophoric when uncovered. When the right eye is covered, hyper deviation occurs – this is suggestive of dissociated vertical deviation.
  • DVD is an innervational disorder found in more than 50% of patients with infantile strabismus (esotropia or exotropia).
  • Usually presents by 2 years of age.
  • Either eye slowly drifts upward and outward, with simultaneous extorsion, when occluded or during periods of visual inattention.
  • Usually, bilaterally asymmetric.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acquired Skew Deviation: A neurological disorder characterized by vertical misalignment of the eyes due to disruption of vestibular or brainstem pathways, often associated with brain lesions or injuries.

 

Option B. Superior Oblique Palsy: A condition caused by weakness or paralysis of the superior oblique muscle, leading to vertical diplopia (double vision), head tilt, and difficulty with downward gaze, especially when looking towards the nose.

 

Option D. Superior Oblique Overaction: A condition where the superior oblique muscle is overactive, leading to excessive inward and downward movement of the eye, often causing a V-pattern strabismus and tilting of images.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dissociated Vertical Deviation (DVD) is a unique type of strabismus where one eye drifts upward when the other eye is fixating, often seen in patients with a history of congenital or early-onset strabismus.

 

Ref: AAO PAEDIATRIC OPHTHALMOLOGY AND STRABISMUS PAGE 139

choices.text: Right Left superior oblique palsy
Right Left inferior oblique palsy

questions.text: Identify the likely muscle involvement from this picture:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right lateral rectus palsy

 

Option B:

 

  • The given test is DIPLOPIA CHARTING.
  • Patient wears red-green goggles (red before right eye and green before left eye).
  • The patient interprets the fine linear light shone at 4ft distance.
  • In the given picture, there is uncrossed separation of images with maximum separation on right gaze suggestive of right lateral rectus palsy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Right medial rectus palsy.

 

 

Option C. Left superior oblique palsy

 

 

Option D. Left inferior oblique palsy

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In diplopia charting, uncrossed separation of images with maximum separation on right gaze suggestive of right lateral rectus palsy.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg no: 353

questions.text: The following images are taken after asking the patient to look up and right, straight up and up and left. Identify the condition:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Double elevator palsy

 

Option C:

 

In the given picture -From left to right (in the right eye):

 

  • Defective elevation on abduction
  • Defective elevation on up gaze
  • Defective elevation on adduction
    • Monocular elevation deficiency or double elevator palsy – characterised by paresis of superior rectus and inferior oblique muscle.
    • Inability to elevate across the horizontal plane.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Superior Oblique Palsy: A condition characterized by weakness or paralysis of the superior oblique muscle, leading to vertical and torsional double vision, often accompanied by a compensatory head tilt.

 

 

Option B. Möbius Syndrome: A rare congenital disorder characterized by facial paralysis and abducens nerve palsy, resulting in limited facial expression and lateral gaze palsy.

 

 

Option D. Brown Syndrome: A disorder characterized by a restriction in the movement of the superior oblique tendon, resulting in difficulty elevating the affected eye, particularly in adduction.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Double Elevator Palsy is rare condition where there is a limitation of elevation in one eye, thought to be due to a palsy of both the superior rectus and the inferior oblique muscles.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg no: 353

choices.text: Base up
Base down
Base out
Base in

questions.text: A patient visits the ophthalmologist with a complaint of inward deviation of the right eye, known as esodeviation. After a thorough evaluation, the ophthalmologist determines that a prism prescription would be beneficial for the patient. What is the ideal orientation or direction in which the prism should be positioned?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Base out

 

Option C:

 

  • To correct convergence the prisms must be base-out.
  • To correct divergence the prisms must be base-in.
  • To correct vertical deviation the orientation of the prisms is opposite for the two eyes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Base up: Positioning the prism with the base upwards is used to correct hypotropia, where one eye is positioned lower than the other. The light path is deviated upwards, helping to align the lower eye with the other.

 

Option B. Base down: This orientation is used for hypertropia, where one eye is higher than the other. The prism base is positioned downwards, deviating the light path downwards to align the higher eye with the fellow eye.

 

Option D. Base in: The base is positioned towards the nose (medially). This is the correct orientation for correcting exotropia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the correction of esotropia, the prism should be positioned with base-out to realign the inward-turned eye outward.

 

Ref: Clinical optics by Elkington page 51
